posts.name: Nevo
posts.cooked: hi i recently wanted to try and sketch an elevator using somepremade parts, but i cant find an elevator bearing block which fits my profile‚Äôs size (20mm x 40mm) all the options online only fit 2x1 or 1x1 inches. can someone help me find a solution please?

Last year we used a 3d printed block that we added small bearings to it with screws worked really well and was very strong.

I will add the cad for it later

https://cad.onshape.com/documents/284e9f8b044c9af5da94a0ff/w/516d668b075cdb138ebc6fdd/e/92ca0f834c2557fff6ba15f7?renderMode=0&uiState=662ce389aa170d1d22fb68cd

We printed 2 holding them with screws that also hold the bearings

posts.name: Brandon Liatys
posts.cooked: Is there a reason you can‚Äôt/don‚Äôt want to use 2x1 or 1x1 tube? These are just about standard sizes in FRC and tons of parts (gussets, bearing blocks, and much more) are designed for. You may be locking yourself out of easy COTS building by not using those tube sizes.

posts.name: Brian Wagg
posts.cooked:
Most likely because it appears the OP is from Israel. Pretty much everything they‚Äôll be able to get their hands on locally will be metric, and shipping large lengths of imperial aluminum tubing would be cost prohibitive.

To OP, I don‚Äôt have a good answer for you. Unfortunately I‚Äôm unaware of any cots suppliers that make FRC specific hardware/kits centered around metric hardware

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
We are experimenting with using 20mm square extrusion for our first-ever elevator (go big or go home, I guess) We will be using 6mm GT2 belts and manufacturing the parts in house (milling the extrusion and 3D printing the prototype brackets, with an eye to milling them of aluminum and HDPE if the 3DP ones work geometrically but have too much friction). Think of the mechanisms in a common 3D printer (Ender et al), just being asked to take 50x the forces.

I‚Äôm very hesitant to guide another team towards our direction as we haven‚Äôt yet proven it works one time in the lab let alone in a single match let alone for a competition season. But if someone wants the CAD for our parts, understanding those risks, we‚Äôll share them.

posts.name: Luuk
posts.cooked:
We have a similar issue as a team that does almost everything with metric components. Therefore, we designed our own bearing blocks that are inspired by the COTS version sold by e.g. REV or Thrifty .

The design fits standard ball bearings (625ZZ) that can be sourced via local webshops, and these are held in place using M5 bolts on the sides. The middle bearings are held by a 5h6 dowel pin, which is locked in place by the bearing block end plate on one side and the tube on the other side. The assembly consists of two plates (2 and 5mm thick) that can be laser cut or milled.

link_counts.title: PRE-ORDER BATCH 2: Sliding Elevator Bearing Block Kit
FRC 4481 Team Rembrandts | 2025 Build Thread | Open Alliance

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
That looks like a great design (and one that I might try to replicate ourselves if our current plastic sliders method doesn‚Äôt work.

Luukyluuk4481:

The middle bearings are held by a 5h6 dowel pin, which is locked in place by the bearing block end plate on one side and the tube on the other side.

I‚Äôm trying to visualize this (specifically the ‚Äúlocked in place by the tube on the other side‚Äù part).

Is there a single dowel passing through both bearings (which I would think is then locked in place by the plates)? Or are there two dowels, one for each of the middle bearings, which would then require the tubes to lock the bearings in place, but I then wonder why not use a single dowel across both, to make for easier/less fiddly assembly.

posts.name: Luuk
posts.cooked:
The dowel pins (sketched red ovals) fit perfectly in the + shape in the middle plate. This + shape has some T-shaped ‚Äúlegs‚Äù to enable us to mill the design. We made some cutouts in the tube to make room for the bearings. We opted for two dowels, because one single long dowel would significantly reduce the stiffness of the middle plate. The tolerances on our + shaped cutout are made in such a way so that there is a slight press fit on the dowel. So we can assemble the bearing block as a separate subassembly before mounting it to our lift tubes.

posts.name: RoboRebels5988
posts.cooked: Thanks, so basically we just need something to hold bearings as rollers on the front and side of the elevator frame to reduce friction,  is that correct? We have not really ever had a good look at an elevator in real life. Thanks for your advice.

posts.name: RoboRebels5988
posts.cooked: Thanks for the info and the pictures. We have lots of bearings we can use. Am I correct in thinking that one set of bearings help the one stage of the elevator frame move up ad down vertically and the 2nd set of rollers are for the inner frame to move? Also why did you use two plates for the assembly instead of one thick one, was it so you can insert the dowel rod? Thanks

posts.name: Luuk
posts.cooked:
We have one set of the bearing blocks mounted on the top side of the fixed stage of our elevator. The other set is mounted at the bottom of the moving stage. The two inner bearings restrain the innerframe in X, and the two outer bearings in Y. In the end the bearings make sure that the elevator has one Degree of Freedom left and that is the movement in Z, the X and Y, and rotational DOFs are restrained. More details can be found on our OA thread, and specifically the pictures in this particular post:

FRC 4481 Team Rembrandts | 2025 Build Thread | Open Alliance FRC Open Alliance

We used two plates to ensure the dowel pin can never fall out. During manufacturing we still aim for a slight press fit of the dowel in the thicker plate, but this might wear a bit due to the forces that these parts experience during a FRC game.
